STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 26, 2024
Tanual Gaskew
House of Love Agency
720 South Michigan Ave.,
Saginaw, MI, 48602
Re: License #: CI730404189
SI #: 2024C0001049SI
Dear Tanual Gaskew:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Nabiha Rizk, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024C0001049SI
Special Investigation Intake Date: January 10, 2024
License #: CI730404189
Licensee Group Organization: House of Love Agency
Licensee Designee: Arneeshia Tamerra Brewer
Chief Administrator: Tanual Gaskew
Agency Name: House of Love Agency
Agency Address: 720 South Michigan Ave.
Saginaw, MI 48602
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 12/23/2025
Capacity: 8
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
1/10/2024 9:00 AM Documentation Special Investigation Initiation
1/10/2024 9:30 AM Phone Other
1/10/2024 3:21 PM Phone Other

1/11/2024 2:00 PM Face to Face Interviewed Youth
1/15/2024 12:00 PM Email Documentation received
1/22/2024 2:14 PM Email Incident notification
1/24/2024 2:14 PM Phone Other

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youths have been knowingly going without medication they are
prescribed. On multiple occasions, youths have been taken to the
hospital due to going without mental health medication they are
prescribed. There have been 61 calls to LE from this facility since
8/10/23 and there are concerns the need of the youths are not
being met.
Investigation This complaint was transferred to DCWL and assigned on
01/10/2024.
On 01/26/2024 additional allegations received noted: Youth C had
medication prescribed that needed to be filled and the agency
refused to pick up the medication, claiming the insurance refused
to pay for the medication.
Interviews:
I interviewed the Complainant via telephone, on 01/10/2024, and
confirmed the information in the allegations.
I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) at the agency, on
01/11/2024. CA reported Youth A was placed at the agency on
11/22/2023 and at the time of placement Youth A had two weeks
supply of medication. She said Youth A’s Foster Care Worker also
provided a refill for two weeks. CA said the process when Youths
are placed at the agency is to schedule psychiatric appointments
with Saginaw County Community Mental Health (CMH), but it has
been a challenge because the earliest appointment for Youth A
was not available until 01/16/2024. CA admitted that the agency
has had to call law enforcement excessively due to youths’
aggressive behaviors, self-harming, and to transport youths to the
emergency department to obtain refills on medication due to not
being able to get earlier appointments with (CMH). CA said the
2

agency policy is the Foster Care Worker is responsibility for
getting the youths medication refilled and Administrator 1 was in
contact with the Foster Care Worker to get Youth A medication
refilled. She further said most of the time Youth A refuses to take
her medication.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 01/11/2024. Staff 1 has
been working at the agency for 6 months and is trained in
medication dispensing. Staff 1 reported the agency policy is
Foster Care Workers are responsible for providing medication at
time of placement and scheduling appointments for Youths to get
refills for their medications. She said Youth A and Youth B were
both hospitalized for self-harming and required refills on their
medication in December 2023. Staff 1 said staff are required to
contact law enforcement when youths are aggressive, self-
harming, injured, or AWOLs. She has contacted law enforcement
due to the youths being assaultive with staff and self-harming.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 01/11/2024. Youth A has
been at the agency since 11/22/2023. Youth A is prescribed
medication for depression, she admitted not taking her medication
daily, because the agency ran out of her medication. She was
hospitalized last month for self-harming.
I interviewed Youth B on 01/11/2024. Youth B reported she was
placed at the Agency on 11/22/2023. Youth B is prescribed
medication for depression. Youth B admitted that she has gone
two weeks without taking her medication. Youth B reported she
had to go to hospital to get medication refilled.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 on 01/24/2024 via telephone.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported Youth A has been in placement for
two months and was initially provided a two-week supply of
medication at the time of placement. Foster Care Worker 1
received a requested on 12/01/2023 from the agency asking for
refill of Youth A’s medication (Hydroxyzine), so she reached out to
Youth A’s previous doctor was able to get Youth two refills. Foster
Care Worker 1 said it difficulty to get an intake appointment with
CMH and the delay did cause an issue with getting Youth A’s
medication refilled. Foster Care Worker 1 confirmed Youth A had
to go to the emergency room to get refills for her medication.
Youth A’s intake appointment with CMH was yesterday and she
has an appointment with a psychiatrist in two weeks. The Foster
Care Worker didn’t specifically say that she was expected to get
the refills, but when the agency reached out and said they were
3

running out of medication Foster Care did step up and try to
contact the previous provider to get the refills.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW 2) on 01/29/2024 via
telephone. Foster Care Worker 2 reported Youth B was placed at
the agency on 11/22/2024 and initially provided with a two-week
supply of her medication. FCW 2 said there was a delay in getting
Youth B’s intake appointment scheduled with Saginaw County
CMH, so Youth B was taken to the emergency department for
self-harming and needed her medication refilled. FCW said the
agency contacted him on 01/01/2024 in reference to getting Youth
B’s medication refilled and he scheduled a telehealth appointment
for Youth B on 01/02/2024 with her previous health care provider.
Consultant 1 interviewed Administrator 1 at the agency on
01/30/2024 in reference to additional allegation received regarding
Youth C’s medication not being filled. Administrator 1 explained
that this issue was related to insurance. Youth C was prescribed a
cough suppressant (not an over-the-counter medication). The
technician at the pharmacy explained there wasn’t a generic or
replacement for the medication prescribed. It was a Friday night
and Administrator 1 sent an email to the team that the pharmacy
had the prescription, but insurance wouldn’t cover it. The team
spoke to the health liaison, but it took a few days to resolve the
issue. By that time, Youth C was discharged to her next
placement. In the meantime, they did a home remedy to help
Youth C cough (hot tea, cough drops, and lemon). Administrator 1
is the one who took Youth C to the emergency department. She
reported Youth C did not have an upper respiratory infection, and
the medication was to assist in suppressing her cough. Even with
the home remedies, the cough subsided. Youth C was given tea
and lemon as often as she wanted. Administrator 1 referenced the
agency made efforts to let Foster Care Worker know that the
insurance did not cover the medication, indirectly indicating it was
not the agency’s responsibility to cover the cost of the medication.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 3 via telephone on 02/14/2024.
Foster Care Worker 3 reported Youth 3 was placed at the agency
on 01/06/2024. Youth 3 was taken to the emergency department
on 01/19/2024 and was prescribed cough suppressant. Foster
Care Worker 3 received an email from Administrator 1 on
01/22/24 stating Youth C was taken to the emergency department
on 01/19/2024, was prescribed cough suppressant, and Youth C’s
insurance did not cover the medication, so the medication was not
picked up by the agency. Foster Care Worker 3 attempted to pay
for the medication over the telephone, but there was an issue with
4

the pharmacy’s payment system. Foster Care Worker 3 called the
agency on 02/23/2024, spoke with staff, but could not recall who
she spoke with, and asked them to pick up the medication and
Foster Care Worker 3 would reimburse the agency. The agency
did not pick up the medication, so the medication was not picked
up until 01/24/2024 by Foster Care Worker 3.
Documentation reviewed for the investigation:
• Health Services Policy and Procedures edited 06/27/2023:
All residents are to be provided with timely, routine medical
dental and medical care. Residents’ medical appointments
will be monitored to ensure routine visits are attended. For
any emergency care needs ambulance or transportation to
the hospital would be arranged.
• Health Services Policy and Procedures edited 01/14/2024:
all residents are to be provided with timely, routine medical
dental and medical care. Residents’ medical appointments
will be monitored to ensure visits are attended. For any
emergency care needs ambulance or transportation to the
hospital would be arranged.
Pyschaitric appointments and medication monitoring will be
overseen by management at initial intake. Intake team will
notify the Foster Care Worker upon admission to secure an
appointment with Great Lakes Bay Health Center or
Saginaw County Community Mental Health.
• Covenant Emergency Care record for Youth A dated
01/09/2024, reason for mental health evaluation.
• Covenant Emergency Care record for Youth B, dated
12/01/2023, reason for visit mental health evaluation,
diagnosis reactive depression.
• Covenant Emergency Care record for Youth B, dated
12/17/2023, reason for visit mental health evaluation,
diagnosis intentional self-harm.
• MDHHS/Agency Contract: Medical and Dental Care. The
Contractor shall assure that children receive routine and
non-routine medical and dental care as required in the
FOM 801, Health Services for Foster Children and the
MDHHS DCWL standards for the license specified in
Section 2.4 of this Contract and as detailed in the
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan. The
Contractor shall provide all medical and dental information
to the primary caseworker/agency to facilitate maintenance
of the Medical Passport (DHS-221). Contract Number:
MA230000001298 In addition, the Contractor shall assure
that specific health care is provided, including: 1)
Rehabilitative, physical, or dental procedures by medical
5

personnel as necessary. 2) Utilization of enrolled Medicaid
providers or a board-certified physician or dentist
volunteering his/her time for health procedures. 3)
Provision of medication as prescribed by a treating
physician. Agency must have a Standard Operating
Procedure for dispensing and storage of medication.
Analysis The facility is in violation of the rule based on interviews and
documentation which clearly shows Youth A and Youth B did not
have all of the prescribed medication available. The youths were
without their prescribed medication, and the agency took them to
the emergency department to get psychotropic medication refills.
The agency policy and procedure for health services is insufficient
to meet the health care needs of the youths.
In reference to the additional complaint received on 01/10/2024
there is rule violation evidence the agency did not pick up Youth
C’s cough suppressant prescription which was prescribed
01/19/2024.
Technical Assistance provided:
The agency was provided consultation regarding having a plan to
cover medication cost of prescription/over the counter medication
that is not covered by insurance.
Conclusion Violation Established.
Rule Code Rules compliance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4104
Section (2) After being licensed, an institution shall, on an ongoing
Description basis, comply with the act, child caring institution rules, and
terms of the license.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency changed the health services policy specifically for
addressing youths’ mental health care needs and did not consult
with licensing priory to changing policy.
6

Investigation I interviewed Administrator 1 on 01/29/2024 via telephone.
Administrator 1 reported the agency changed the Health Services;
Policies and Procedures on 01/14/2024.
I interviewed Consultant 1 on 02/13/2024 via telephone.
Consultant 1 reported the agency did not consult or provide the
updated Health Services Policies and Procedures prior to
changing the policy. Consultant 1 reported he met with
Administrator 1 on 05/24/2023 and 07/19/2023 and discussed
complying with licensing when changing/updating policy.
Documentation reviewed for the investigation:
• Health Services Policy and Procedures edited 06/27/2023:
All residents are to be provided with timely, routine medical
dental and medical care. Residents’ medical appointments
will be monitored to ensure routine visits are attended. For
any emergency care needs ambulance or transportation to
the hospital would be arranged.
• Health Services Policy and Procedures edited 01/14/2024.
Medical: Residents medical appointments will be monitored
to ensure routine visits are attended. Psychiatric
appointments and medication monitoring will be overseen
by management at initial intake. Intake team will notify the
Foster Care Worker upon admission to secure
appointments with Great Lakes Bay Health Center or
Saginaw County Community Mental Health.
Analysis The agency is in violation of the rule based on interviews and
documentation. The agency changed Health Services Policy and did
not consult with Licensing. Furthermore, the policy is insufficient and
does not meet the rule requirement for addressing youths medical,
dental, and behavioral health care.
Conclusion Violation Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
02/23/2024
______________________________________________________________________
Nabiha Rizk Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 27, 2024
_____________________________________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
